attributes.title: Fruit and other Natural Sweeteners
attributes.description:
Created on June 25, 2010 by ShaynaHarris on Sourcemap.org:

Fruits and natural sweeteners that come from family farmers around the world.

attributes.name: Fruit and other Natural Sweeteners
attributes.title: Fruit and other Natural Sweeteners
attributes.description: Fruits and natural sweeteners that come from family farmers around the world.

attributes.name: Strawberries
attributes.title: Strawberries
attributes.description: J: We purchase 60% of our strawberries from California, and the rest from Mexico and Argentina.  This ensures us a steady supply of strawberries throughout the year.

attributes.name: Acai
attributes.title: Acai
attributes.description:
J: Acai originates from the Amazon rainforest in Brazil.	PHOTO SLIDESHOW


FF:
Sambazon is the only source of Organic and Fair Trade Açaí, which means we know exactly where our acai comes from and we can ensure it’s harvested sustainably and our farmers are treated fairly.

Sambazon works directly with a network of over 10,000 family farmers responsible for over 1.9 million acres of agro - forestry farms that protect the natural biodiversity of their rainforest land.

attributes.name: Sugar
attributes.title: Sugar
attributes.description: J: Brazil is the world’s largest organic and conventional  sugar producer and exporter.  Stonyfield purchased more organic sugar last year than the whole US organic sugar market produced, making it essential that we look abroad for an organic sugar supply.

attributes.name: Raspberries
attributes.title: Raspberries
attributes.description: Gambling on organic from Stonyfield on Vimeo.

attributes.name: Strawberries
attributes.title: Strawberries
attributes.description:
J: We purchase 60% of our strawberries from California, and the rest from Mexico and Argentina.  To ensures a steady supply of strawberries throughout the year

	FF: 98% of the energy needed to cultivate conventional strawberries comes from non-renewable resources, in large part due to the highly toxic chemical fertilizers required to grow the plants.  In contrast, less than over half of the energy used to cultivate organic strawberries, such as those Stonyfield uses in it yogurt, comes from renewable energy sources.  Organic strawberry growers not only reduce their reliance on oil, but they also reduce the costs of their inputs from costly chemical fertilizers.  (Source: http://www.agroecology.org/Case%20Studies/strawberries.html)

attributes.name: Sugar
attributes.title: Sugar
attributes.description:
Paraguayan Sugar Inc

J: Paraguay is second to Brazil in global organic sugar production.  Tthe majority of its organic sugar producers are small family farmers. 
	FF: Since our supplier began sourcing organic sugar in Paraguay, there has been a ten-fold increase in land that is dedicated to organic production.  There are now well over 2000 individual small farmers who participate in the production of our organic sugarcane.


PHOTO SLIDESHOW
Created with Admarket's flickrSLiDR.

attributes.name: Honey
attributes.title: Honey
attributes.description:
Click here to learn more about our honey from Brazil

J: It is extremely difficult to source organic honey, as organic regulations stipulate that five miles of the land around beehives must be organic certified, and that’s just hard to find these days anywhere but Brazil!  	FF:

Our honey comes from small-scale beekeepers in Brazil whose primary activities are on their farm.  The honey provides an additional source of income for the region’s farmers.  Some of our beekeepers work next to the Araripe National Forest in Brazil, providing fertile ground for bee pollination while also protecting important forest systems. (Source: Cearapi)

attributes.name: Bananas
attributes.title: Bananas
attributes.description:
Click here to learn more about  the COOP of farmers producing our Bananas from Costa Rica 

J: The world banana trade is dominated by a few countries - Ecuador and Costa Rica are on top. 

	FF: The family farmers who supply Stonyfield’s bananas come from indigenous communities in Costa Rica.  They take an agroecological approach to farming, which means growing crops in a symbiotic was with nature, and intercropping to allow for nutrient-rich soil, integrated pest management, and income diversification.

attributes.name: Wild Blueberries
attributes.title: Wild Blueberries
attributes.description:
J: 80% of the world’s wild blueberries grow in Canada. 

SFF: Wild blueberries are harvested deep within the forest by local Quebecoise, generating both income and promoting environmental conservation.

Blueberries from the forest from Stonyfield on Vimeo.

Created with Admarkets flickrSLiDR.
